Award.AwardTitle: Beyond the Thermal WIMP Paradigm: Theoretical Motivations and Experimental Signatures
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Rouzbeh Allahverdi at the University of New Mexico.

We know from observations that only 15% of the matter in the universe is described by the Standard Model of particle physics, while 85% is made of dark matter (DM). However, the nature and origin of DM remains one of the most profound problems at the interface of particle physics and cosmology. A whole array of direct- and indirect-detection experiments, combined with the successful running of the Large Hadron Collider, will help us discover the DM and establish its particle-physics origin. The complementary information provided by these experiments will also play a crucial role in explaining the DM content of the universe. The research funded by this award will study theoretical models and observational signatures of DM production mechanisms beyond the dominant paradigm based on the notion that the DM consists of weakly interacting massless particles. Research in this area thus advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical law. The research funded by this award will also have significant broader impacts. Professor Allahverdi will involve graduate and undergraduate students in his research, and thereby provide critical training to junior physicists beginning research in this field. The PI will additionally bring his results to a broader audience through job shadowing and mentorship of high-school students, as well as by visiting schools and giving public lectures.

More technically, the research supported by this award focuses on scenarios of non-thermal DM production having a two-fold goal. First, the PI wishes to study novel theoretical models and distinct experimental signals of non-thermal DM. In several extensions of the Standard Model, the DM is produced in a non-thermal fashion. Second, the PI wishes to explore interesting connections between primordial black holes (PBHs) and non-thermal DM that can arise in a universe with non-standard thermal history. To achieve these objectives, Professor Allahverdi will build new particle-physics models of non-thermal DM, test their observational signals via DM indirect-detection experiments and structure-formation data, and examine consequences of possible connections between PBHs and DM in these models. These investigations will help us determine the theoretical origin of DM and its embedding within a fundamental theory. They will also enable us to use DM as a window to the thermal history of the universe when it was only a tiny fraction of a second old. This is far earlier than that provided by the current observational probes involving the cosmic microwave background or Big-Bang nucleosynthesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We know from observations that only 15% of the matter in the universe is described by the standard model (SM) of particle physics, while 85% is made of dark matter (DM). However, the nature and origin of DM remains as one of the most profound problems at the interface of particle physics and cosmology. The research funded by this award focused on theoretical models and experimental signals beyond the "WIMP miracle" paradigm. It included investigations on non-thermal production of DM having a two-fold goal. First, to study novel theoretical models and distinct experimental signatures of non-thermal DM. Second, to explore interesting connections between primordial black holes (PBHs) and non-thermal DM that can arise in a universe with non-standard thermal history. These investigations help us determine the deeper theoretical origin of the DMsector and its embedding within a fundamental theory. They will also enable us to use DM as a window to the thermal history of the universe when it was a tiny fraction of a second old.

The important findings of our investigations can be summarized as follows:

(1) We have propsoed novel scenarios of non-thernal DM production that involve primordial black holes (PBHs) formed and evaporated via Hawking radiation in the first second after the big bang. This scenario can accommodate the correct relic abundance for weak scale DM masses.

(2) We identified new regions in the parameter space that reporduce the observed DM abundance in reallistic non-standard thermal histories. Parts of these regions, while evading detection by DM direct and indirect searches, may be probed via collider experiments and coosmological observations. 

(3) We have constructed explicit particle physics models of the early universe that give rise to non-standard theral histories. Non-thermal production at various stages of the universe evolution during the first second after the big bang can yield the correct relic abundance foir superheavy DM.

(4) In collaboration with several other well-known experts, we have written a review article on non-standard expansion histories, their consequences, and observational probes. This timely review can be used by the community in future research on this topic.

The research funded by this award also had significant broader impacts. It involved both graduate and undergraduate students in research, thereby providing critical training to junior physicists beginning research in this field. One Ph.D. student supprted by this award successfully defended his thesis in 2019. Two undergraduate students worked toward their honors thesis on topics related to this research in 2019 and 2020. The research was also used as a vehicle to help a high school student with his senior thesis on a related topic in 2019.

The research funded by this award led to the following notable products:

(1) Articles in peer-reviewed journals: four published papers plus two papers currently under review.

(2) One Ph.D. thesis.

(3) Two undergraduate honors theses.
